days_to_first_flower_note: 70-100 days from sowing to first bloom depending on variety
frost_tolerance: Frost sensitive — sow after last frost
watering: Moderate — water deeply but infrequently once established
companion_plant_note: Excellent companion; attracts pollinators and predatory insects, deters aphids
staking_note: Tall varieties need staking in windy positions
notes: Direct sow where it will grow — dislikes root disturbance. Sow after soil warms in spring. Deadhead to extend flowering.

days_to_first_flower_note: 60-75 days from sowing to first bloom
watering: Moderate — keep evenly moist
companion_plant_note: Good pollinator attractor for vegetable gardens
staking_note: Not required for dwarf types in sheltered positions
notes: Varieties like 'Teddy Bear', 'Big Smile', and 'Eos' are excellent dwarf patio sunflowers. Good for kids' gardens.

days_to_first_flower_note: 60-80 days from sowing to first bloom
watering: Moderate — water at base; avoid wetting foliage
companion_plant_note: Outstanding companion plant — root secretions repel nematodes; strong scent deters whitefly, aphids, and other pests
notes: One of the best vegetable garden companions. Plant as a border around the veggie patch. Deadhead regularly for continuous bloom.

days_to_first_flower_note: 50-60 days from sowing to first bloom
watering: Moderate
companion_plant_note: Excellent companion — repels aphids, whitefly, and nematodes; attracts beneficial insects
notes: French marigolds are more compact and bushier than African types. Ideal for pot edges and between vegetable rows. Prolific bloomer.

days_to_first_flower_note: 60-70 days from sowing to first bloom
watering: Moderate — water at base; avoid wetting foliage to prevent powdery mildew
companion_plant_note: Attracts pollinators and beneficial predatory insects
notes: Direct sow after soil warms — dislikes root disturbance. Thrives in Melbourne, Sydney, and Adelaide summers. Cut regularly to encourage more flowers. Dwarf varieties great for pots.

days_to_first_flower_note: 60-90 days from sowing to first bloom
watering: Low to moderate — thrives on neglect; overwatering causes lush growth with few flowers
companion_plant_note: Attracts lacewings, parasitic wasps, and other beneficial insects
notes: Thrives in poor soil — do NOT over-fertilise or you get all leaves and no flowers. Self-seeds readily. Excellent cutting flower. Pinch seedlings for bushier plants.

days_to_first_flower_note: 45-60 days from sowing to first bloom
frost_tolerance: Light frost tolerant once established; seedlings frost sensitive
watering: Low — drought tolerant once established; overwatering reduces flowering
companion_plant_note: Excellent companion — flowers and leaves are edible; acts as a trap crop for aphids; deters whitefly and squash bugs
notes: Both flowers and leaves are edible — a peppery flavour great in salads. Direct sow where it will grow. Compact varieties: 'Jewel Mix', 'Empress of India'. Self-seeds readily.

days_to_first_flower_note: 55-70 days from sowing to first bloom
watering: Low to moderate
companion_plant_note: Edible flowers and leaves; trap crop for aphids
staking_note: Provide a trellis, fence, or hanging basket to trail over
notes: Varieties like 'Gleam Mix' and 'Climbing Mix' trail vigorously. Beautiful in hanging baskets. Edible flowers have a spicy, peppery flavour.

days_to_first_flower_note: 90-120 days from sowing to first bloom
frost_tolerance: Hardy — tolerates moderate frosts; seedlings benefit from cool conditions
watering: Regular — keep evenly moist especially during flowering
companion_plant_note: Fixes nitrogen in soil; attracts pollinators
staking_note: Must have a trellis, netting, or tall wire support — climbing tendrils need something to grip
notes: IMPORTANT: Sow in autumn/winter in temperate Australia — sweet peas need cool growing conditions to set flowers. They fail if sown in spring. Soak seeds overnight before sowing. Nick seed coat to aid germination. Highly fragrant. Pick flowers constantly to prolong flowering season.

days_to_first_flower_note: 50-70 days from sowing to first bloom
watering: Moderate — fairly drought tolerant once established
companion_plant_note: Excellent companion — attracts aphids away from vegetables (trap crop), repels asparagus beetles, attracts pollinators and beneficial insects
notes: One of the easiest flowers to grow in Australian gardens. Sow in autumn for winter/spring flowers. Petals are edible and used in salads and as a saffron substitute. Self-seeds prolifically. Deadhead to prolong blooming.

plant_life: Annual (grown as cool-season annual in Australia)
sun_requirements: Full sun to part shade — prefers cooler positions in warmer months
days_to_first_flower_note: 60-80 days from sowing; often bought as seedlings
frost_tolerance: Hardy — tolerates moderate frosts; actually prefers cool conditions
watering: Moderate — keep evenly moist; wilts quickly in heat
difficulty: Moderate (easier to buy seedlings than grow from seed)
companion_plant_note: Edible flowers; attracts pollinators in winter
notes: Pansies need darkness to germinate — cover seed tray with cardboard. Struggle in heat; plant in autumn for winter/spring display. Edible flowers. Deadhead to extend flowering.

days_to_first_flower_note: 55-70 days from sowing to first bloom
watering: Moderate
companion_plant_note: Edible flowers; ground cover that suppresses weeds between plants
notes: More heat tolerant and self-seeding than pansies. Violas are smaller-flowered but more floriferous and easier to grow. Self-seeds readily in the garden.

sun_requirements: Full sun to part shade — prefers some afternoon shade in hot climates
days_to_first_flower_note: 70-90 days from sowing to first bloom
sowing_depth: Surface sow — press gently into moist mix, do not cover
frost_tolerance: Frost sensitive as seedling; established plants tolerate light frost
watering: Moderate — keep evenly moist; does not like drying out
difficulty: Moderate (tiny seeds — easiest to start in punnets)
companion_plant_note: Attracts pollinators; good edging plant
notes: Tiny seeds — do not cover, just press onto surface of moist seed-raising mix. Takes patience. Easier to buy seedlings. Cut back after first flush of flowers to encourage a second flush.

sun_requirements: Part shade to full sun — trailing types prefer part shade
days_to_first_flower_note: 70-90 days from sowing to first bloom
watering: Moderate — trailing types in pots dry out quickly; check daily in summer
companion_plant_note: Excellent for hanging baskets and pot edges
notes: Classic hanging basket plant. Cascades beautifully over pot edges. Shear back halfway after the first flowering peak to rejuvenate. Water containers frequently in Australian summer.

plant_life: Annual (self-seeds freely, behaves like a perennial)
days_to_first_flower_note: 40-60 days from sowing to first bloom
sowing_depth: Surface sow — press lightly, needs light to germinate
watering: Low to moderate
companion_plant_note: Excellent companion — ground cover suppresses weeds; honey-scented flowers attract hoverflies and parasitic wasps that prey on aphids and caterpillars
notes: Honey-scented and a powerhouse beneficial insect attractor. Shear back in midsummer if it goes straggly — it will bounce back. Self-seeds prolifically. Plant between brassicas as a pest deterrent.

sun_requirements: Full sun — needs at least 6 hours daily
days_to_first_flower_note: 70-90 days from sowing — most gardeners buy seedlings
sowing_depth: Surface sow — tiny seeds need light to germinate; do not cover
watering: Moderate — regular watering; allow to dry slightly between waterings to prevent root rot
difficulty: Moderate (very tiny seeds; most buy seedlings)
companion_plant_note: Repels asparagus beetles, tomato hornworm, leafhoppers, and aphids
notes: Grandiflora types have large flowers but less weather tolerance; Multiflora types have smaller blooms but are more weather resistant — better for Australian summers. Deadhead or shear back for continuous blooming. Feed regularly with liquid fertiliser for best performance.

plant_life: Annual (short-lived perennial; grown as cool-season annual in Australia)
days_to_first_flower_note: 70-100 days from sowing to first bloom
sowing_depth: Surface sow — press gently, needs light to germinate
frost_tolerance: Hardy — tolerates moderate frosts; prefers cool conditions to flower
watering: Moderate — keep evenly moist
companion_plant_note: Attracts pollinators; repels aphids and tomato hornworm
staking_note: Tall varieties may need light staking in windy positions
notes: Prefers cool weather to set flowers — best planted in autumn for winter/spring display. Struggles in hot summers. Pinch out growing tip when young to encourage bushier plants. Dwarf varieties excellent for pots.

days_to_first_flower_note: First flowers may take 12-18 months from seed; buy established plants for faster results
sowing_depth: Surface sow — needs light; barely cover
frost_tolerance: Hardy — very frost tolerant; actually needs cold winters to perform well
watering: Low — drought tolerant once established; overwatering kills lavender
difficulty: Difficult from seed — buy seedlings or propagate from cuttings
companion_plant_note: Deters aphids, whitefly, and codling moth; attracts bees and pollinators
notes: CAUTION: Slow from seed — germination rate is low and plants take 1-2 years to establish and flower. Most gardeners buy seedlings or strike cuttings. English lavender performs best in cooler climates (Melbourne, Adelaide highlands). Prune lightly after flowering — never cut into old wood. Needs excellent drainage; hates wet feet.

days_to_first_flower_note: 60-80 days from sowing to first bloom
frost_tolerance: Hardy — tolerates frosts; actually prefers cool growing conditions
watering: Low to moderate — drought tolerant once established
companion_plant_note: Attracts pollinators and beneficial insects; edible flowers
staking_note: Tall varieties may need light staking
notes: Direct sow where it will grow — does not like root disturbance. Sow in autumn for spring flowers in cooler climates. Beautiful classic blue flowers, also available in pink, white, and burgundy. Self-seeds readily. Flowers are edible.

days_to_first_flower_note: 80-110 days from sowing to first bloom
sowing_depth: Surface sow — tiny seeds need light; mix with sand for even distribution; do not cover
watering: Low — drought tolerant
companion_plant_note: Attracts pollinators in spring
notes: Must be direct sown — does not tolerate transplanting. Needs cold to trigger germination (cold stratification). Scatter seed on bare ground in autumn and let winter cold do the work. Self-seeds prolifically and will naturalise.

plant_life: Annual to biennial (grown as annual in warm climates)
days_to_first_flower_note: 90-120 days from sowing to first bloom
watering: Low to moderate
companion_plant_note: Attractive spring display; attracts pollinators
notes: Sow in autumn for a spectacular spring display of papery, tissue-like flowers. Cannot survive summer heat — it is a cool-season plant. In temperate Australia, sow March to April. Does not transplant well — direct sow or use biodegradable pots.

plant_life: Annual (self-seeds freely — behaves as perennial in the garden)
sun_requirements: Full sun — needs full sun to open flowers
days_to_first_flower_note: 60-90 days from sowing to first bloom
sowing_depth: Surface sow — scatter and lightly rake in
watering: Low — thrives on neglect; overwatering inhibits flowering
companion_plant_note: Attracts pollinators; naturalises in dry garden areas
notes: Must direct sow — cannot transplant. Brilliant orange cups. Thrives in poor, dry soils. Self-seeds prolifically and will return every year. Flowers close at night and on cloudy days. Perfect for Australian dry gardens and slopes.

days_to_first_flower_note: May not flower until second year from seed; first flowering around 12 months
frost_tolerance: Hardy — very frost tolerant; needs cold winters
watering: Low — drought tolerant once established
companion_plant_note: Spectacular spring flowers; dies back in summer
notes: Dies back completely in summer — mark location so you don't disturb roots. Re-emerges in autumn. Large, spectacular flowers with distinctive black markings. Best in cooler climates (Melbourne, Adelaide). Does not perform as well in Sydney summers.

plant_life: Biennial (some modern varieties perform as annuals)
days_to_first_flower_note: Usually flowers in second year from seed; some annual varieties flower in 120+ days
frost_tolerance: Hardy — tolerates moderate to severe frosts
watering: Moderate
companion_plant_note: Tall background plant; attracts pollinators and butterflies
staking_note: Tall flower spikes need staking in windy positions
notes: Classic cottage garden biennial — sow in spring/summer to flower the following spring/summer. Some annual varieties (e.g. 'Spring Celebrities') can flower same year. Prone to rust disease — ensure good air circulation. Self-seeds readily. Beautiful planted along fences and walls.

sun_requirements: Part shade to full sun — prefers dappled shade in hot climates
days_to_first_flower_note: Flowers in second year from seed, usually October to December
sowing_depth: Surface sow — needs light to germinate; do not cover
watering: Moderate — keep evenly moist; dislikes drying out
companion_plant_note: Woodland plant; attracts native bees
notes: CAUTION: All parts of foxglove are toxic — wear gloves when handling. Sow in spring/summer for flowers the following year. Self-seeds readily in suitable conditions. Prefers a woodland edge setting with cool moist conditions. Struggles in harsh Australian summers — performs best in cooler areas (Dandenong Ranges, Adelaide Hills, Southern Highlands).

plant_life: Perennial (often grown as annual in Australian conditions)
sun_requirements: Full sun — needs full sun but cool conditions
days_to_first_flower_note: 120-150 days from sowing to first bloom
watering: Regular — needs consistent moisture; dislikes drought
difficulty: Difficult — challenging in hot Australian summers
companion_plant_note: Tall, dramatic border plant; attracts pollinators
staking_note: Tall flower spikes must be staked — very vulnerable to wind damage
notes: CAUTION: All parts are toxic. Challenging in warm Australian climates — performs best in cooler areas (Melbourne, Adelaide Hills, Canberra, Highlands). Needs cool weather to set flower buds; hot dry summers cause decline. Refrigerate seeds for 1 week before sowing to improve germination. Slugs and snails are major pests.

days_to_first_flower_note: 70-90 days from sowing to first bloom
sowing_depth: Surface sow — press lightly; needs light to germinate
watering: Moderate
companion_plant_note: Attracts pollinators; deters carrot fly and cabbage moth
notes: Salvia splendens (scarlet sage) is the classic bright red annual bedding salvia. Salvia viridis (painted sage / clary) has colourful bracts. Both are excellent summer performers in Australian gardens.

scientific_name: Salvia nemorosa / Salvia x sylvestris / Salvia officinalis
days_to_first_flower_note: May not flower significantly until second year from seed; best propagated by cuttings or division
watering: Low — drought tolerant once established
companion_plant_note: Deters cabbage moth, carrot fly, and aphids; attracts pollinators
notes: Perennial salvias are tough, drought-tolerant once established, and long-lived. Cut back hard after flowering to encourage repeat blooming. Excellent Mediterranean-style garden plants for all temperate Australian cities.

plant_life: Annual to short-lived perennial (usually treated as annual in Australia)
days_to_first_flower_note: 80-100 days from sowing to first bloom
frost_tolerance: Frost sensitive as seedling; established plants tolerate light frost
watering: Moderate — fairly drought tolerant once established
companion_plant_note: Attracts butterflies, native bees, and seed-eating birds in autumn
notes: Note: Do not confuse with Thunbergia alata — the vine also called 'Black-eyed Susan' in Australia. Rudbeckia hirta (Black-eyed Susan daisy) is a prairie-style flower with golden-yellow petals and a dark brown centre. Summer to autumn flowering. Long-lasting cut flower.

days_to_first_flower_note: May not flower until second year from seed; established plants flower reliably each summer
watering: Low — drought tolerant once established
companion_plant_note: Outstanding pollinator plant — attracts native bees, butterflies, and seed-eating birds when seed heads left over winter
notes: Cold stratification (refrigerate moist seeds for 4 weeks) greatly improves germination. Slow growing in first year — patience required. Once established, very long-lived and drought hardy. Leave seed heads standing for winter bird interest. Prized for medicinal use. Excellent Australian native bee plant.

sun_requirements: Full sun to part shade — afternoon shade beneficial in hot climates
days_to_first_flower_note: 120-150 days from sowing to first bloom
sowing_depth: Surface sow — seed should be sown upright (pointed end down), barely covered; needs light
frost_tolerance: Frost sensitive — protect from hard frosts
watering: Moderate — water at base; crown rot is a major problem; avoid wet crown
companion_plant_note: Bright, cheerful flowers; attracts pollinators
notes: IMPORTANT sowing tip: Gerbera seed has a feathery tail — sow with the pointed (bare) end down and tail up, barely covered with mix. Seeds lose viability quickly — use fresh seed. Plant crowns must be planted high (crown above soil level) to prevent crown rot. Excellent cut flower.

plant_life: Annual (grown from seed as annual; can overwinter tubers)
days_to_first_flower_note: 90-120 days from sowing to first bloom
frost_tolerance: Frost sensitive — tubers/plants killed by frost
watering: Moderate to regular — needs consistent moisture in summer
companion_plant_note: Attracts pollinators; tall varieties provide light shade
staking_note: Taller seed varieties may need light staking
notes: Seed-grown dahlias (e.g. 'Figaro', 'Bishop's Children', 'Unwins Dwarf Mix') are compact and flower in the first year. Unlike tuber-grown dahlias which can be very tall, seed types stay small. In temperate Australia, sow seeds indoors in late winter/early spring and transplant after last frost.

plant_life: Annual to biennial (Carnation is short-lived perennial; Sweet William is biennial)
days_to_first_flower_note: 80-120 days from sowing to first bloom (Sweet William often flowers second year)
frost_tolerance: Hardy — tolerates moderate to hard frosts
watering: Moderate — excellent drainage essential; hates waterlogged soil
companion_plant_note: Fragrant flowers attract pollinators; some repel aphids
notes: Dianthus chinensis (annual pinks) flowers quickly in first year. Sweet William (D. barbatus) is biennial — sow spring/summer for flowers next spring. Annual pinks are excellent cool-season performers in Australian gardens. Spicy clove-like fragrance. Deadhead for continuous blooming. Must have well-drained soil.

sun_requirements: Part shade to full shade — KEY feature: one of very few flowers that blooms well in shade
days_to_first_flower_note: 70-90 days from sowing; most gardeners buy seedlings
sowing_depth: Surface sow — needs light to germinate; do not cover
frost_tolerance: Frost sensitive — killed by light frost
watering: Regular — needs consistent moisture; wilts dramatically when dry but usually recovers with watering
difficulty: Moderate (very tiny seeds; most buy seedlings)
companion_plant_note: Ideal shade garden plant under trees and in dark spots
notes: THE classic shade-loving annual. Brings colour to shadowy spots where most flowers fail. Does NOT tolerate direct afternoon sun — leaves scorch and flowers drop. New Guinea Impatiens are more heat and sun tolerant. Downy mildew has been an issue in some areas — check for resistant varieties.

days_to_first_flower_note: 60-90 days from sowing to first bloom (annual types faster)
frost_tolerance: Moderately hardy — tolerates light frost; perennial types very frost hardy
watering: Low to moderate — drought tolerant; excellent drainage essential
companion_plant_note: Classic florist filler flower; attracts pollinators
notes: Prefers alkaline (sweet) soil — add lime if soil is acidic. Excellent for drying and as a cut flower filler. Successive sowings every 4-6 weeks for continuous supply. Annual type (G. elegans) best for home gardens. Dislikes root disturbance — direct sow.

plant_life: Annual (grown as annual; some species are perennial)
days_to_first_flower_note: 90-120 days from sowing to first bloom
frost_tolerance: Frost sensitive as seedling; light frost once established
watering: Low — drought tolerant; hates waterlogged soil
companion_plant_note: Excellent for drying and coastal gardens; attracts pollinators
notes: Outstanding dried flower — retains colour for years when dried. Also salt tolerant, making it good for coastal gardens near Sydney and Melbourne bayside. Start indoors 8-10 weeks before last frost or sow direct in spring. Can be slow to germinate.

plant_life: Annual to short-lived perennial (annual in temperate climates)
sun_requirements: Full sun — needs maximum sun to produce papery blooms
days_to_first_flower_note: 70-90 days from sowing to first bloom
sowing_depth: Surface sow or barely cover — needs light
watering: Low — very drought tolerant; overwatering causes rot
companion_plant_note: Australian native genus; attracts native bees and butterflies
notes: This is actually an Australian native genus. Thrives in the Australian climate. Harvest flowers for drying BEFORE fully open for best colour retention. Simply hang upside down in a warm, dry spot for 2-3 weeks. One of the best everlasting flowers for dried arrangements. Very heat tolerant.

days_to_first_flower_note: 55-70 days from sowing to first bloom
watering: Low — drought tolerant once established
companion_plant_note: Outstanding companion plant — deters tomato hornworm and cabbage moth; attracts bees and beneficial insects; edible blue star-shaped flowers taste of cucumber
notes: Flowers and young leaves are edible — flowers taste like cucumber and are beautiful frozen in ice cubes or used in salads and cocktails. Direct sow where it will grow — tap root dislikes disturbance. Self-seeds so prolifically that once you plant it, you effectively have it forever. Bees absolutely love it.

sun_requirements: Part shade to full sun — prefers dappled shade in hot climates
days_to_first_flower_note: Flowers in late winter to spring from autumn sowing — approximately August to October
sowing_depth: 3-6mm — cover lightly; prefers some darkness to germinate
frost_tolerance: Hardy — very frost tolerant; thrives through winter
watering: Moderate — keep moist; dislikes drying out
companion_plant_note: Traditional companion for spring bulbs; covers dying bulb foliage; attracts early pollinators
notes: Sow in late summer to autumn for a magical late winter/spring display of clear blue flowers. Classic cottage garden plant. Self-seeds prolifically and will naturalise in moist, part-shaded spots. Perfect underplanted with tulips and daffodils — the forget-me-nots hide the fading bulb foliage. Dies off when summer heat arrives.
